messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON  JAPANESE SWORDS
messages.msgSnippet: ... Still more cleaning... Mark- General MacArthurs basement was located in Akabane a former Imperial Japanese Armory taken over by US forces and one of
messages.messageBody:
On Jan 5, 2006, at 10:55 AM, Mark Jaillet wrote:

> Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated
> at the
> end of the war? There must have been thousands taken. Were they
> destroyed? Brought back to the US? Mccarthy's basement?
>
> Mark
>

Still more cleaning...

Mark-
General MacArthurs' basement was located in Akabane a former
Imperial Japanese Armory taken over by US forces and one of several
spots where confiscated weapons were collected and warehoused. Over
the years several attempts were made by the Tokyo government to
return swords to their owners. Once they were sure there would be no
more claims made, the swords were examined, sorted and the average to
better ones restored. These were then returned to the prefectual
governments of their respective places of origin. Thus swords from
Sesshu went to Osaka and swords from Musashi stayed in Tokyo. Some of
them turn up on display in the local museums and there was a catalog
from one of the more recent exhibitions if I remember correctly. Look
for akabane-to...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Sue - There is a dealer in San Antonio named Mike Quigley who definitely tell you about your tanto. See what he can say about the tanto and then before
messages.messageBody:
Hi Sue -

There is a dealer in San Antonio named Mike Quigley who definitely tell you about your tanto. See what he can say about the tanto and then before moving too quickly, get a couple more opinions from this list. A few good photos can work relatively well. Any number of us would be more than happy to have a look-see.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Sue Belzer
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 2:25 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


I have a tanto that was given to my uncle by the family with whom he was
billeted after WWII. I'm still trying to find someone in the San Antonio
area who can examine it and tell us what can be deduced about its maker,
history, etc. Unfortunately, my uncle is long gone, and not available for
questions.

On 1/5/06, John Berta <johnberta@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Mark;
>
> Yes to all the above. Unfortunately a lot were destroyed.
>
> John
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Mark Jaillet
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 10:55 AM
> Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS
>
>
> Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated at the
> end of the war? There must have been thousands taken. Were they
> destroyed? Brought back to the US? Mccarthy's basement?
>
> Mark
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
> Behalf Of sigp210
> Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 1:32 PM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS
>
>
> I'd just like to add that the serial numbered swords are limited to
> the NCO shin guntos with aluminium cast handle. I have seen many other
> so-called Japanese swords with serial numbers on the blade, and these
> were almost all Chinese fakes. For some reason, they think this
> increases the value or legitimacy.
> After the war, most of the civilian swords (bar a few identified as
> art objects) were confiscated, not registered.
> There is very little chance of tracking down the original owners or
> history of 99% of these swords.
>
> Regards,
> Brian
>
> >
> > Hello David -
> >
> > Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too.
> >
> > If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the
> blade) then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made" sword.
> Sometimes you will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) of a
> sword, usually two or three digits, which in that case might relate to
> "assembly" numbers; these same numbers are often repeated on seppa,
> tsuba, etc. Swords were "registered" after the war and continue to be
> so today, but the Japanese government never required anything
> (registration numbers) to be stamped on swords.
> >
> > Ron
> > STL
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: dpoll64
> > To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> > Sent: Wednesday, January 04, 2006 3:12 PM
> > Subject: [nihontostudy] SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS
> >
> >
> > Firstly, happy new year and nice to meeet you all. I am new
> at
> > this so I have a question that one of you may be able to help
> > me with.
> >
> > After WWII did the Allies make the Japanese register their
> > swords and were the swords stamped with a serial number after
> > registration?
> >
> > If this is true, does anybody know how I can get access to
> > these registers so that I can trace the history of these
> > numbered swords.
> >
> > regards
> >
> > David
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON  JAPANESE SWORDS
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mark; Yes to all the above.  Unfortunately a lot were destroyed. John ... From: Mark Jaillet To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Thursday, January 05,
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mark;

Yes to all the above. Unfortunately a lot were destroyed.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Mark Jaillet
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 10:55 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated at the
end of the war? There must have been thousands taken. Were they
destroyed? Brought back to the US? Mccarthy's basement?

Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of sigp210
Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 1:32 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


I'd just like to add that the serial numbered swords are limited to
the NCO shin guntos with aluminium cast handle. I have seen many other
so-called Japanese swords with serial numbers on the blade, and these
were almost all Chinese fakes. For some reason, they think this
increases the value or legitimacy.
After the war, most of the civilian swords (bar a few identified as
art objects) were confiscated, not registered.
There is very little chance of tracking down the original owners or
history of 99% of these swords.

Regards,
Brian

>
> Hello David -
>
> Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too.
>
> If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the
blade) then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made" sword.
Sometimes you will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) of a
sword, usually two or three digits, which in that case might relate to
"assembly" numbers; these same numbers are often repeated on seppa,
tsuba, etc. Swords were "registered" after the war and continue to be
so today, but the Japanese government never required anything
(registration numbers) to be stamped on swords.
>
> Ron
> STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: dpoll64
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Wednesday, January 04, 2006 3:12 PM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS
>
>
> Firstly, happy new year and nice to meeet you all. I am new
at
> this so I have a question that one of you may be able to help
> me with.
>
> After WWII did the Allies make the Japanese register their
> swords and were the swords stamped with a serial number after
> registration?
>
> If this is true, does anybody know how I can get access to
> these registers so that I can trace the history of these
> numbered swords.
>
> regards
>
> David
>
>
>
>
>
>
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

messages.msgSnippet: Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated at the end of the war?  There must have been thousands taken.  Were they destroyed?
messages.messageBody:
Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated at the
end of the war?  There must have been thousands taken.  Were they
destroyed?  Brought back to the US?  Mccarthy's basement?
 
Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of sigp210
Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 1:32 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


I'd just like to add that the serial numbered swords are limited to
the NCO shin guntos with aluminium cast handle. I have seen many other
so-called Japanese swords with serial numbers on the blade, and these
were almost all Chinese fakes. For some reason, they think this
increases the value or legitimacy.
After the war, most of the civilian swords (bar a few identified as
art objects) were confiscated, not registered.
There is very little chance of tracking down the original owners or
history of 99% of these swords.

Regards,
Brian

>
> Hello David -
>
> Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too.
>
> If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the
blade) then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made" sword.
Sometimes you will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) of a
sword, usually two or three digits, which in that case might relate to
"assembly" numbers; these same numbers are often repeated on seppa,
tsuba, etc. Swords were "registered" after the war and continue to be
so today, but the Japanese government never required anything
(registration numbers) to be stamped on swords.
>
> Ron
> STL

>   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

at

>   me  with.
>
>   After  WWII did the  Allies  make  the  Japanese  register their

>   regards

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] SERIAL NUMBERS ON  JAPANESE SWORDS
messages.msgSnippet: Hello David - Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too. If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the blade) then you have a mass produced so-called
messages.messageBody:
Hello David -

Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too.

If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the blade) then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made" sword. Sometimes you will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) of a sword, usually two or three digits, which in that case might relate to "assembly" numbers; these same numbers are often repeated on seppa, tsuba, etc. Swords were "registered" after the war and continue to be so today, but the Japanese government never required anything (registration numbers) to be stamped on swords.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: dpoll64
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, January 04, 2006 3:12 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


Firstly, happy new year and nice to meeet you all. I am new at
this so I have a question that one of you may be able to help
me with.

After WWII did the Allies make the Japanese register their
swords and were the swords stamped with a serial number after
registration?

If this is true, does anybody know how I can get access to
these registers so that I can trace the history of these
numbered swords.

regards

David
